metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin (Huailai station-lysimeters, 2017)
metadata.description:
The data set contains the observation data of the evapotranspiration apparatus on January 1, 2017 (solstice) and December 31, 2017.The site is located in huailai county, hebei province, east garden town, the underlying surface for corn.The latitude and longitude of the observation point is 115.7880E, 40.3491N, and the altitude is 480m.
The collection frequency of the evapotranspiration permeameter is 1 time/min, and the released data is 10min output data.The evapotranspiration meter is a cylindrical structure with a surface area of 1m2 and a buried depth of 1.5m. The observation accuracy of evapotranspiration is 0.01mm.Two evapotranspiration seeptometers were installed, one kept bare soil (lysimeter_1), the other for the corn underlay (lysimeter_2) during the growing season (May 10 - September 15).Soil temperature and humidity probe, soil water potential probe and soil heat flow plate are also installed in the evapotranspiration apparatus.The buried depth of the soil temperature sensor is 5cm, 30cm, 50cm, 100cm and 140cm.The buried depth of the soil water sensor is 2cm, 10cm, 20cm and 40cm.The soil heat flux plate is buried 10cm underground;The buried depth of the soil water potential sensor was 30cm and 140cm.Processing and quality control of observation data :(1) ensure 144 data per day (every 10min). If data is missing, it will be marked by -6999;(2) delete the data of observation anomalies caused during maintenance;(3) data that is obviously beyond the physical meaning or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the format of date and time is unified, and the date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: 2016-6-10-10:30.
The observation data released by the evapotranspiration permeameter include:Date/Time, weighing mass (i.l._1_wag_l_000 (Kg), i.l._2_wag_l_000 (Kg)), seepage mass (i.l._1_wag_d_000 (Kg), i.l._2_wag_d_000 (Kg)), soil heat flux (Gs_1_10cm, Gs_2_10cm) (W/m2),Multi-layer soil moisture (Ms_1_5cm, Ms_1_10cm, Ms_1_30cm, Ms_1_50cm, Ms_1_50cm, Ms_1_100cm, Ms_2_5cm, Ms_2_10cm, Ms_2_30cm, Ms_2_50cm, Ms_2_100cm) (%),Multi-layer soil temperature (Ts_1_5cm, Ts_1_30cm, Ts_1_50cm, Ts_1_100cm, Ts_1_140cm, Ts_2_140cm, ts_2_2_5cm, ts_2_2_50cm, Ts_2_100cm, Ts_2_140cm) (℃), soil water potential (TS_1_30 (hPa), TS_1_140 (hPa), TS_2_30 (hPa), TS_2_30 (hPa), TS_2_140 (hPa), TS_2_140 (hPa));The data is stored in *.xls format.

background: Based on the measurements of lysimeter, eddy covariance (EC), and automatic weather station (AWS) in Huailai Remote Sensing Experiment Station in 2012 and 2013, the daily and seasonal variation of soil evaporation and maize field evapotranspiration have been analyzed. The relationship between field evapotranspiration and meteorological factors (net radiation, air temperature, air humidity, and wind speed), soil moisture has been studied through multiple regression analysis method. Lysimeter’s representativeness was significantly affected by the growth of the crops within it. As heat can not be exchanged between the soil in lysimeter and the soil outside, the average temperature of the soil in the lysimeter is 9.5% higher than that of the field outside.
research objective: This article utilizes observation data from the evaporation and infiltration instrument at the Chinese Academy of Sciences Remote Sensing Comprehensive Experimental Station in Huailai, Hebei, from May to September in 2012 and 2013. It calculates soil evaporation, crop evapotranspiration, rainfall, and leakage during the corn growing season. By combining meteorological factors, it explores the daily and seasonal variation patterns of soil evaporation and crop evapotranspiration. Additionally, it compares and analyzes the observation results of evapotranspiration from the eddy covariance instrument and the evaporation and infiltration instrument to verify the representativeness of the latter. It also preliminarily analyzes the reasons for the differences between the two, providing a reference for future research on agricultural irrigation decision-making and water-saving in agriculture.
challenges: The evaporation and infiltration instrument is a single-point observation tool with a relatively small observation range, thus its spatial representativeness is limited. Therefore, it is essential to verify whether the observation results of the evaporation and infiltration instrument can represent the evapotranspiration values of farmland within the regional scope. Even after energy closure correction, the evapotranspiration measured by the eddy covariance instrument is lower than that of the evaporation and infiltration instrument, which shows an overestimation phenomenon. Strong Xiaoman and others believe that the evaporation and infiltration instrument isolates the water and heat exchange with the surrounding farmland, leading to differences in soil moisture supply and heat exchange within the instrument compared to the surrounding farmland, which may result in the overestimation of evapotranspiration by the evaporation and infiltration instrument.
methods: To study the variation characteristics of farmland evapotranspiration in the North China region, a multi-scale evapotranspiration observation system was set up in the study area. The experimental area is divided into irrigated land and dry land by the red line shown in the figure. A 10 m meteorological tower and a 40 m meteorological tower were installed in both the irrigated land and dry land, equipped with automatic weather stations and eddy covariance instruments. The soil moisture and energy balance systems were installed at the 10 m meteorological tower located in the irrigated land. According to the experimental requirements, one of the two soil moisture instruments was kept bare, serving as a comparison, while the other was planted with corn. To ensure that the growth conditions of the corn in the soil moisture instrument were consistent with those of the surrounding farmland corn during the experiment, corn of the variety Zhengdan 958 was planted on one of the soil moisture instruments on May 5, 2012, and May 10, 2013. The sowing time, row spacing, and plant spacing were consistent with those of the surrounding farmland, and regular weeding was conducted in the soil moisture instrument to ensure that the growth of corn inside was as consistent as possible with that of the surrounding farmland.
dataset: The evaporation and infiltration instrument used in this study is a weighing lysimeter produced by the German company UMS, model Hydro-Lysimeter. It was installed on September 11, 2011, in a field located about 300 meters east of the experimental station, approximately 10 meters from the external road of the field. The lysimeter has a cylindrical structure with a surface area of 1 m² and a height of 1.5 m, with an evapotranspiration measurement accuracy of 0.1 mm. The two lysimeters share a maintenance well, which is equipped with two leakage buckets for measuring the leakage amount from the lysimeters, with a measurement accuracy of 0.01 mm. Additionally, both lysimeters are equipped with sensors for soil water potential, soil temperature, soil moisture, and soil heat flux.
findings: The result shows that the daily variation curves of soil evaporation were quite consistent with maize field evapotranspiration, while seasonal differences were obvious. In the region of Huailai, net radiation and soil moisture obviously correlated with daily evapotranspiration, while other factors did not obviously correlate. The correlativity between evapotranspiration measured by EC and that by lysimeter is very good. The value of lysimeter is 10.5% higher than that of EC. As a result, the evapotranspiration of lysimeter is relatively larger.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that ensures the accuracy and reliability of soil moisture and temperature measurements in agricultural research?
Example.Answer: A data collection method that ensures accuracy and reliability in agricultural research involves using a lysimeter with soil moisture and temperature sensors installed at multiple depths. The sensors provide data that include soil moisture content at depths of 2cm, 10cm, 20cm, and 40cm, and soil temperature at depths of 5cm, 30cm, 50cm, 100cm, and 140cm. This helps in understanding soil moisture and temperature dynamics crucial for agricultural research.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using lysimeters to measure evapotranspiration in agricultural fields?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced when using lysimeters to measure evapotranspiration in agricultural fields is their limited spatial representativeness. Since lysimeters are single-point observation instruments, they might not accurately represent the evapotranspiration values over a larger field area. Additionally, the isolation of the lysimeter from the surrounding soil can lead to differences in heat and moisture exchange, potentially causing an overestimation of evapotranspiration measurements.

Definition.Question: What does a 'lysimeter' mean in the context of soil and crop evapotranspiration studies?
Definition.Answer: A lysimeter is an instrument used for measuring the amount of water that is lost from the soil due to evaporation and plant transpiration. It is typically a cylindrical structure with a known surface area and depth, such as 1m² surface area and 1.5m depth, used to study soil evaporation and crop evapotranspiration by isolating a section of soil and its vegetation. The lysimeter allows for precise measurement of water input and output, providing data on evapotranspiration and other related factors.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with using lysimeters for measuring evapotranspiration in agricultural fields?
Definition.Answer: The challenges associated with using lysimeters for measuring evapotranspiration include their limited spatial representativeness due to being single-point observations. Additionally, they can overestimate evapotranspiration because they isolate soil and vegetation from surrounding fields, interrupting natural water and heat exchange processes. This isolation can result in differences in soil moisture supply and heat exchange compared to the surrounding area.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using multiple regression analysis in studying the relationship between field evapotranspiration and meteorological factors?
Definition.Answer: Multiple regression analysis is significant in studying the relationship between field evapotranspiration and meteorological factors because it allows researchers to quantitatively analyze how various factors such as net radiation, air temperature, air humidity, wind speed, and soil moisture contribute to evapotranspiration. This analytical method helps in understanding the complex interactions and determining the most influential factors affecting evapotranspiration in a given region or under specific conditions.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection technique using a lysimeter compare to that using an eddy covariance system in terms of measuring field evapotranspiration?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection using a lysimeter involves direct measurement of evapotranspiration by weighing changes in soil mass, which provides high precision but may have limited spatial representativeness due to the isolation of the soil column. In contrast, the eddy covariance system measures fluxes over larger areas, providing broader spatial coverage but may underestimate evapotranspiration compared to lysimeters, as indicated by a 10.5% higher measurement from the lysimeter.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in spatial representativeness between data collected by lysimeters and automatic weather stations in agricultural fields?
Comparison.Answer: Lysimeters provide point measurements and have limited spatial representativeness, as they isolate a small volume of soil and may not account for heterogeneities in the surrounding area. Automatic weather stations, on the other hand, collect data over a broader area, capturing more spatial variability in meteorological conditions but may not capture detailed soil processes as lysimeters do.

Interpretation.Question: How might the separation of heat and water exchange between the lysimeter and surrounding soil affect the accuracy of evapotranspiration measurements?
Interpretation.Answer: The separation of heat and water exchange can lead to the lysimeter displaying higher soil temperature and potentially higher evapotranspiration rates compared to the surrounding soil, which might result in an overestimation of the evapotranspiration values.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the installation of sensors at various soil depths contribute to understanding soil moisture and temperature dynamics in agricultural fields?
Interpretation.Answer: Installing sensors at various depths allows for detailed monitoring of soil moisture and temperature profiles, helping to reveal how these factors vary throughout the soil column and affect plant growth and water usage over time.

Interpretation.Question: What potential challenges can arise from using a single-point observation system like a lysimeter for representing regional agricultural evapotranspiration values?
Interpretation.Answer: A single-point observation system like a lysimeter may have limited spatial representativeness, making it necessary to verify if its measurements can accurately reflect the broader area's evapotranspiration values, especially considering environmental variations such as crop growth and microclimate differences.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the lysimeter to overestimate evapotranspiration compared to other measurement methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The lysimeter's isolation from surrounding soil prevents heat exchange, resulting in a higher soil temperature and potentially leading to an overestimation of evapotranspiration.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the limited spatial representativeness of single-point lysimeter measurements?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The confined nature of lysimeters and their inability to account for spatial variability in soil and crop conditions limit their representativeness for broader field evapotranspiration measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to ensure consistent growth conditions in and around the lysimeter for accurate data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: To ensure that the lysimeter's measurements reflect true field conditions, consistent growth conditions are necessary to align the microenvironment within the lysimeter with the surrounding fields, thus minimizing discrepancies in water and heat exchange.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using lysimeter measurements for evaluating evapotranspiration over a larger agricultural region?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Lysimeter measurements have limited spatial representativeness due to their single-point nature. This can lead to discrepancies when extrapolating data to represent larger areas, as lysimeters often isolate soil from external heat and water exchanges. This isolation may cause the lysimeter to overestimate evapotranspiration compared to surrounding fields.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the implications of seasonal crop growth on the representativeness of lysimeter data in agricultural research?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Seasonal crop growth can significantly influence lysimeter data, as the crop within the lysimeter may not exchange heat and water with its surroundings in the same way as the field crops. This can lead to higher soil temperatures and potentially higher evapotranspiration measurements within the lysimeter, affecting the representativeness of data for broader agricultural research.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to analyze the correlation between meteorological factors and field evapotranspiration using lysimeter data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Analyzing the correlation between meteorological factors and field evapotranspiration is important to understand how factors such as net radiation, air temperature, air humidity, and wind speed influence soil moisture and evapotranspiration rates. This understanding can improve irrigation decision-making and agricultural water management, providing insights into the environmental conditions that affect crop growth and water use efficiency.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the objective behind ensuring the consistency of growth conditions between crops inside lysimeters and the surrounding farmland?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to ensure that the lysimeter observations accurately represent the evapotranspiration and growth conditions of the surrounding farmland. By maintaining consistent growth conditions, such as planting the same maize variety with identical planting times, spacing, and regular weeding, the study aims to minimize discrepancies between the lysimeter and the actual field conditions, thus enhancing the reliability and applicability of the data collected for agricultural research and water management.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in ensuring the accuracy and precision of evapotranspiration measurements using lysimeters in agricultural research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In agricultural research, to ensure the accuracy and precision of evapotranspiration measurements using lysimeters, the setup involves installing lysimeters with a cylindrical structure and maintaining specific conditions such as bare soil and crop cover during growth seasons. Data quality control is implemented by ensuring the completeness of daily data records, removing anomalies caused by maintenance, and eliminating data that exceed physical meanings or instrument ranges.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key steps involved in setting up a multi-scale evapotranspiration observation system in a research area to study soil and crop water dynamics?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Setting up a multi-scale evapotranspiration observation system involves establishing a network of instruments including meteorological towers with automatic weather stations, eddy covariance systems, and lysimeters. These are strategically placed in irrigated and non-irrigated areas to capture diverse conditions. The lysimeters are configured to represent different surface conditions, such as bare soil and crop cover, to closely match the surrounding field conditions. Regular maintenance and alignment with local agricultural practices ensure consistency in data collection.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of different sensor systems enhance the accuracy of soil evaporation and crop evapotranspiration data collection?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of lysimeters with eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations allows for comprehensive data collection, providing insight into soil evaporation and crop evapotranspiration variations by correlating meteorological factors such as net radiation and soil moisture.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary to ensure the representativeness of lysimeter data in reflecting broader agricultural field conditions?
Enablement.Answer: It is crucial to maintain consistent growth conditions within the lysimeter and the surrounding fields, such as planting the same maize variety with identical sowing times, row, and plant spacing. Regular maintenance, like weeding, is also needed to ensure representativeness.

Expectation.Question: Why might a lysimeter's measurements of evapotranspiration differ from those of other methods such as eddy covariance?
Expectation.Answer: Lysimeter's measurements can be higher than those from eddy covariance because a lysimeter isolates the soil within it from the surrounding environment, affecting heat and water exchange. This isolation can lead to higher soil temperatures and potentially overestimated evapotranspiration values.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in ensuring that lysimeter-based data accurately represents regional evapotranspiration values?
Expectation.Answer: A key challenge is the limited spatial representativeness of lysimeter data, as it is a point measurement. The isolation of the lysimeter from its surroundings can result in different water and heat exchange conditions compared to the broader region, potentially leading to discrepancies in evapotranspiration values.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using lysimeter data in representing broader regional agricultural evapotranspiration values, considering its spatial limitations?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness of using lysimeter data is limited by its spatial representativeness, as it provides single-point observations. There is a need to verify whether lysimeter observations can represent field-scale evapotranspiration values. The data tends to overestimate evapotranspiration due to the lack of water and heat exchange between the inside of the lysimeter and surrounding field conditions.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges and limitations in ensuring consistent growth conditions between crops inside the lysimeter and those in the surrounding fields?
Judgmental.Answer: Ensuring consistent growth conditions involves challenges such as maintaining identical planting times, spacing, and regular maintenance like weeding. Differences in water and heat exchange between the lysimeter and surrounding fields may lead to discrepancies in growth conditions, potentially affecting the accuracy of evapotranspiration measurements.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the data collection frequency and the processing protocol ensure the accuracy and reliability of the observed soil and meteorological parameters.
Assertion.Answer: The data collection frequency is set at one measurement per minute, with data being output every 10 minutes. This high frequency allows for detailed monitoring of changes in soil and meteorological parameters. The processing protocol includes ensuring the completeness of daily data (144 data points), marking missing data with -6999, and removing anomalies caused by maintenance or data points that exceed physical or instrumental ranges. This ensures that the data is accurate and reliable.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the installation depth of various sensors within the lysimeter affects the overall data quality and representation of soil conditions.
Assertion.Answer: Sensors within the lysimeter are installed at various depths to capture a comprehensive profile of soil conditions. Soil temperature sensors are placed at depths of 5cm, 30cm, 50cm, 100cm, and 140cm, while soil moisture sensors are at 2cm, 10cm, 20cm, and 40cm depths. This ensures that variations in soil temperature and moisture at different levels are accurately captured, providing a detailed understanding of the soil profile, which is crucial for assessing evapotranspiration and other soil processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and summarize the various data collection methods for measuring soil evaporation and crop evapotranspiration in agricultural fields.
Request/Directive.Answer: The field utilizes lysimeter measurements, eddy covariance (EC), and automatic weather stations (AWS) to analyze soil evaporation and crop evapotranspiration. The lysimeter is a key instrument for measuring evapotranspiration, particularly in maize fields, and it provides detailed insights into the relationship between evapotranspiration and meteorological factors such as net radiation and soil moisture. These methods help in understanding daily and seasonal variations in soil and crop water fluxes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the challenges faced in ensuring the spatial representativeness of evaporation and evapotranspiration data collected in agricultural research.
Request/Directive.Answer: Lysimeter data collection faces challenges in spatial representativeness due to its single-point observation nature, which limits its ability to represent regional farmland evapotranspiration accurately. The separation of the lysimeter from surrounding soil can lead to discrepancies in water and heat exchange, potentially causing an overestimation of evapotranspiration. This challenge necessitates validation against broader measures like the eddy covariance method to ensure regional applicability.
